commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Getaway where guests are out of fashion?  (6)(4)
2. When ties get untied, for short  (4)
3. Bold choice, perhaps?  (8)
4. One who tries to make a good impression  (7)
5. Nothing needs to be said to do it  (3)


NUDIST CAMP
INOT
TYPEFACE
DENTIST
HUM
Easy Monday puzzle. Until I spelled teem with an A. Ah well
Got the whole puzzle in 10:26 without knowing what the theme is!! Seriously, I still don‚Äôt know the theme üòÖ

Vaer: sotto voce appreciates your concern. She sends her love wants you (and anyone else who‚Äôs concerned about her) to know that she‚Äôs OK. She just needs a little break from Wordplay and hopes to be back here soon.

Thanks for asking after her.
Can we point out how amazing this is for a Monday? It really takes the cake.
If you raced through this one, why not try a slightly harder Margaret Seikel puzzle? https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2023/05/09

Great Monday I am always impressed by clues where both the beginning and end fit the theme. Minor nit, you can only take THE cake whereas you take A powder, A puff, etc. But a minor inconsistency in an otherwise excellent theme and well constructed puzzle.

A very pleasant puzzle for a very pleasant (lazy) Sunday! Cute theme! I also especially liked ARFS at 31 across, for pound sounds.

And I'm also very excited to say that I will be going to hear Stacey ABRAMS speak later this week for MPR's Talking Volumes show.

I‚Äôm going to take a stand and say the revealer takes the cake. For a Monday I had a hard time figuring it out. Take a number if you did too. 

I initially thought the letters IM were removed (i.e. ‚Äútaken‚Äù) from the answers. But of course I couldn‚Äôt make any sense of that. 

I had to take a break before I finally understood the theme. 

 Margaret, take a bow.

When I'm on fall break, leaf me alone.

(That joke is acorn-y one.)

HeathieJ:

I just saw your comment about your broken freezer. Eeew.

My husband's cousin's wife once left a raw chicken in the back of her car for a day or so. In Austin in the summer.
Wouldn't it be Take a STAND, Take a NUMBER, and Take a PUFF?

I'M quite TAKEN with your CALM approach to cluing.  Perfect for a Sunday afternoon‚ÄîI could almost hear the WAY a COW LOWeS in the evening on a FARM when the TEAM rounds up the TEEMing herd and says AMEN to the day.

You gave us a lovely puzzle, not TUTU hard, and not too easy.  Thank you!  (No need to CURTSY, I'll do that.) 

I'd include a link to Whitman's poem "When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom'd," but I don't like it very much.  (Was that a NASTY comment?)

Loved this one!!  A fun one! In the South, we ‚Äútake a powder‚Äù for a headache by taking a BC Powder - a crushed up pain killer. If we say, ‚ÄúI need to take a powder.‚Äù it usually means we have a headache.
Happy new solving week, everyone! I hope this puzzle made no one say, ‚ÄúI need to take a powder!‚Äù
Thanks, Margaret!
Fun and easy puzzle today, 19 seconds shy of my PB.  I didn't understand the theme until reading this column but wasn't necessary to get the answers.
Fun one!

SECOND CHANCE
TOLL CALL
FLIGHT RISK

Sigh, so am I the only one the site blipped on after finishing the puzzle?  And now I have a blue stop to a streak?  This has only happened 3 times before, and this is the first where I'm fairly sure there was no network issue on my side.  :(

I had let the first 2 or 3 slide but just had the silly thing repaired a month ago.

Well, I had giants instead of GREATS and I stand by the opinion that it would have been a fun literal pun (with an ‚Äú?‚Äù of course)! I chuckled a bit as I confidently entered the wrong word, thinking to myself that this was my favorite entry so far. Well duh!

Am I the only one who found this quite hard and not very interesting? Apparently, but I'm used to being the odd man out around these parts ü§£. I solved the puzzle, but in Tuesday time, and I found neither the clueing nor the theme special. It was OK, but I really can't see why many posters before me professed their love for this grid. 

I enjoyed seeing ACDC though. "Highway to Hell" is a likely candidate for music at my funeral ü§£.

Lucyfer the poodle puppy does something new and cute every day. Last night he played with his own reflection in the terrace window üòç. He's also very calm and brave for a puppy. The day before last we took him to Warsaw's Wis≈Ça (Vistula) waterfront, one of the city's most crowded places, teeming with locals and tourists alike. Lucek didn't seem stressed at all. He took in all the sights, sounds and smells, and it looked like he enjoyed it. üôÇ
Easy breezy Monday üòä I had POPTop before POPTAB, but easily corrected on the crosses. Thank you, Margaret, for your TAKE on this one. Nice start to the week.
As good as I have gotten at crosswords, I don't think I will ever be clever enough to come up with cool themes like this one! Loved it. Bravo!

I've been having trouble the last few days viewing the whole puzzle on my laptop due to a NYT banner advertising some family subscription at the top that won't go away, forcing me to scroll back & forth, up & down to do the puzzle. Very annoying. Please help.
A revealer has to ‚Äúreveal‚Äù to work. ‚ÄúTake a number‚Äù and ‚Äútake a seat‚Äù, ok. But ‚Äútake a puff‚Äù is a stretch and ‚Äútake a powder‚Äù?! Sorry. No.

For a Monday puzzle, this takes the CAKE!  I often love a challenge but sometimes it‚Äôs nice to take a breath and ease into a new week. Was enjoying the fresh clueing‚Ä¶. And then I was swept away by aha of the revealer!  Who knew so many phrases include ‚Äútake a ____‚Äù, and then that putting two of them together would also form phrases? Quite the feat!!
Solving the clues felt like a Monday puzzle.  Understanding the theme felt like a Thursday puzzle.
I see the asterisks, but shouldn't the revealer and theme entries be yellow-highlighted when selected? They weren't for me.
Isn't the observatory on Mauna Kea and not Mauna Loa?

Nice start to the week. Count me as another one who was oblivious to the theme.

My biggest hangup was 47D; I had trouble figuring out wat kind of [attache] they were talking about. Also, a slight quibble with 15D. I think the natural words are either POPtop or pullTAB, but not the credited response.

Thanks for the reminder of happier days in 36A.

I love that this puzzle starts at 1A with CALM.  My first thought at the finish was how lovely the fill-in felt, and ‚Äúcalm‚Äù is the perfect description.  It felt as if I were in an easy chair. Ahhh...

Calm but not boring, mind you, no, there were interesting things ‚Äì the fun theme and confirming that it worked by checking out each word in the theme answers, lovely answers like LILAC, CURTSY, ROIL, and DAB, and that nailed-it revealer of I‚ÄôM TAKEN.  

Lovely to see the symmetrical palindromes EVE and AHA.  Lovely to see the theme echo of answers in the grid that can be taken: PLEA, CURTSY, and MED.

NUMBER spurred other words ending with the er-sound that can be taken: GANDER, LETTER, PICTURE.

Fun afterward to meta the theme:
FALL BREAK ‚Äì take a vacation.
SEAT NUMBER ‚Äì take a chair.
CAKE STAND ‚Äì take a bite.
POWDER PUFF ‚Äì take a moment.

Anyway, I left the grid feeling peaceful and happy, and how sweet is that?  Take a listen, please, Margaret ‚Äì thank you!

Good fun theme.  Many thanks. 

[Seize an unexpected opportunity?]

CHANCESHOT

Fun Monday puzzle. A bit on the slow side for me but once I caught on to the theme it all fell together. That's always a nice touch. A perhaps appropriate puzzle find today. I imagine most of us may have done this one, but I had completely forgotten it. Anyway - a Thursday from August 3, 2023 by Simeon Siegel. The reveal clue and answer in that one was; "Get some rest ‚Ä¶ or what to do with the end of the previous answer to solve each starred clue :" TAKEFIVE Not easy to describe this one, but here are some pairs of across answers with the clue to the second answer: 13a: ASSIGNOR 15A: "*Complete fools." AMUSES So the implied answer to 15a with taking five from the previous answer would be: IGNORAMUSES A couple of other examples with the paired across clues and then the implied answers: FOREVER / BERATES REVERBERATES SHINDIG/NATION INDIGNATION STRAPS/HOOTERS TRAPSHOOTERS Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/3/2023&g=63&d=A I'm done. ...

I painted myself into some silly corners with wild guesses on this one. Not as smooth as my usual Monday, but in a nice way. I guess I had to create obstacles for myself to get my brain cracking this morning!
20A was a little misleading for me. All my prayers end in "or else."
Huzzah! Today was a personal best. I didn‚Äôt understand the theme until I read the Wordplay, but no matter.

Meh.
I'M not TAKEN with this puzzle.

But at least it has its own NIT built in.

Fun Monday! Thought the reveal of the theme was fun, and I liked that you had to think about it a bit more than you would a typical theme to get the eventual joke.
 For a while I thought it was going to be based around classic American high school experiences (Powder Puff Football, Homecoming Dance, Assigned Seating) but I liked the twist chosen here better. 
Was a bit frustrated with ALL, ROIL, and ARFS being paired, as I felt the cluing for all three of these was quite weak. C'est la vie - overall a fun puzzle!
What the hell is an ARF
NYT crossword constructor Paolo Pasco on Jeopardy on 9/10 Wednesday

Nice Monday puzzle.  I like that the "TAKE" worked with both halves of the themed answer.
A mild NIT on the use of both "TAKE a ___" and "TAKE the ___"
But no biggy.

But I was thinking about the phrase "I'M TAKEN" as a "polite rejection at a dance."  
It's hard to imagine a man uttering that line (except jokingly).
And it's hard to imagine a (modern) woman saying that either.  Would *anyone* want to think of themself as "TAKEN"?

This is more an inquiry into contemporary usage than a criticism of the puzzle.  I think the theme is just fine.
In today‚Äôs puzzle, 34 down hint is ‚ÄúHit on a vape pen‚Äù and the answer is DAB however this is inaccurate. Dabs are taken on rigs, not on vape pens. As an avid consumer, this really irked me.

I've always thought "take a powder" referred to taking a bathroom break, as in going to the "powder room." It can also be used to allude to being annoyed and needing a break from people/situation. "I/you need to take a powder!"

I read the revealer, and then quickly forgot it. After finishing the puzzle (quickly, but not as quick as my usual Mondays), I had to read the column to understand the theme. That's okay though; I enjoyed it and felt it was Monday-level enough to start my week well. 

Started off wrong with grill instead of FRYER. Also had dirty instead of NASTY.  The annoying little neighbors next door (who are only annoying when they are outside; adorable when I visit inside) were yapping away when I hit ARFS, so they get credit for that part of my fill. My ADbuys got in the way of ADRATE but CAKESTAND took care of that. And suddenly, I was done!

For some reason, Apple has decided I am not allowed to access my own email address, so I cannot get to it before Wednesday. It has been a long week without it; I can't see when my comments are approved, or know if I have important messages coming in. No fault of my own, mind you, according to the Apple support person. Ten days altogether until I can get back to it. Frustration is mounting. On the other hand, just to have something productive to do, I have cleaned out all my emails (four addresses) and am almost at inbox zero. If only losing weight were so easy!

I am wondering if there is anyone, having solved enough puzzles for a good statistical sample, whose weekday solving times graph does not look like a set of stairs. Mine look like a normal set of stairs.

Are you taking the Mickey? A themeless Monday puzzle?

Take a memo: always read the clues all the way through. Yes, I found the revealer, eventually. Take a bow, Ms Seikel.

A couple of late puzzle finds, initially inspired by wondering about something like 'THETHECHECKMAIL' ("the check is in the mail). Well - nope, that's never been done, but that has been an answer, and that lead me in a roundabout way to some others. First - a Sunday from October 2, 2016 by Zhouqin Burnikel with the title "Paper Jam" Several rebuses in that one . Some examples: FREEDOMOFTHE(press) / crossing DE(press) RE(news) crossing / HUEYLEWISANDTHE(news) WHATINTHE(world) crossing / SMALL(world) BEHINDTHE(times) crossing / AT(times) JUSTFORTHE(record) crossing / PRISON(record) And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/2/2016&g=38&d=D ....

Re: take a powder, meaning to take off, it appears to have originated as the phrase "take a run-out powder" which was early 1900s slang. The phrase implied taking a powder (medicine) that made a person run fast or run away. Like a "run-away powder". Looks like it started as baseball or boxing slang then entered hobo vernacular then general usage in films and Broadway. https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/156736/why-does-to-take-a-powder-mean-to-run-away-or-to-leave

I saw "A Chorus Line" about ten years ago and one woman was conspicuously taken aback by the vulgar language(and I don't mean American English). Every single person from the orchestra to the balcony took notice.

In the second act when one character sang about his alternative lifestyle, she took offense, exception and umbrage. She wasn't gonna take it anymore. She took flight, took her leave, took a hike. 

True story, take my word for it.

(Today's column photo was clearly taken from "A Chorus Line".)

So I rate this puzzle
Dance: 10
Looks:    3

Pleasantly tricky for a Monday - not tough overall, but a lot more skipping clues and circling back around than I'm used to for starting things off. It was a nice way to get my brain in gear for the week.
Now that was a very cool Monday puzzle. Fun and clever.

@NYC Traveler,

Thanks for pointing me to the Strands puzzle today!! I only do Strands occasionally, and most likely would not have today, so I really appreciate it!! 

But how strange... I don't understand how you knew that I like Star Trek so much!?  

You must be some kind of genius wizard!! üòÜüññ

Today's lyric comes courtesy of Stephen Schwartz, from The Magic Show:

Ain't it rotten feelin' like a second fiddle,
A third nostril, a fourth musketeer?
Ain't it rotten feelin' like a fifth wheel?
Well your sixth sense oughta tell you dear
Before the hints get any louder 
Now's the time to TAKE A POWDER
You're about as welcome as a skunk at a tea
Two's company, which makes you nothin' but a C-R-O-W-D
Take a bow, Margaret. Lovely Monday puzzle!

After solving I like to review the grid and take in the answers. Several made me smile today. I love lemon AIOLI with French Fries. If you haven't tried it, you are missing out. I miss 36A and 43D, class acts. In my barre class we do one legged CURTSY squats until our bums ache! Nice saucy Monday. 

Speaking of ADRATEs, does it seem like a good marketing strategy to force subscribers to block ads in order to see the whole puzzle grid and clues? No issues on my tablet, just the laptop. Still annoying.

Feedback on the new Pips game: Today I did the easy puzzle in 38 seconds, the medium in 42 seconds, and I gave up on the hard one after 35 minutes of trying. Consider making the medium puzzle closer to halfway between easy and hard? Enjoying it.

And... another puzzle- A Sunday from May 9, 2004 by Charles M. Deber with the title "Moving the bar." Here are a couple of theme clues and answer: Clingy duchess? : SARANFERGUSON Comment about a mixed public reaction? : SOMELIKEITNOT And some other theme answers: SNOWBUSINESS NEROSWELCOME NASTYPUDDING GARDENNOSE And there were more. Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/9/2004&g=121&d=A .....

And... one more puzzle find. By Peter Gordon from 2016. Four 15 letter theme answers from top to bottom. Here those are: DUETOBUDGETCUTS THENEWYORKTIMES CROSSWORDPUZZLE WILLENDTOMORROW And the date of that puzzle? April 1. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/1/2016&g=34&d=A ...

Thanks, Margaret Seikel, for a zippy and delightful Monday puzzle. I had a very busy weekend so it was only this morning I started on the big Sunday puzzle. I finally finished that (after a break for my daily walk) and got to today‚Äôs. There‚Äôs always a pretty big difference between the Sunday and Monday puzzles, and doing them back to back made it more pronounced. I enjoyed both of them and I‚Äôm so grateful to have all the NYT puzzles and all the clever constructors and editors who bring them to us. And I always enjoy your comments too, Sam.

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Traffic director]  (4)
[Sound from a chicken]  (3)


CONE
EEK
INOT had me confused for a moment; I was wondering if untying ties is something that's practiced in occupational therapy...

@Bob
I presume that over time you came to understand it.

Bob,

I hear you can study OT at DOOK.
@Megan Did the exact same thing!  Added a minute to my time looking for my mistake
@Megan My fingers also did this to me.

Peter,

Maybe reread the 39A clue? Seriously!
@Barry Ancona I saw the 39A, I just didn't understand what it meant....

@Eric Hougland
Thanks Eric.

@Vaer

You're welcome.

Peter,

I gather you found the theme...

@Barry Ancona

A first for me.

I thought, sure, I'd like to do another one.  Clicked on your, and I had already done it.

It doesn't feel like over a year since I started all this.

@SP
But both are TAKEN...  think again.

@HeathieJ

Yay! Love that lady!

@Beth in Greenbelt

Yeah, me too! I'm super excited!! And the Fitzgerald theater, where it'll be held is so beautiful!! Wish you could join us!! ‚ò∫Ô∏è

@Beth in Greenbelt
As a native of Georgia (even though I lived there only a few years in total) I follow the politics and news...  Stacey ABRAMS is a force of nature!  I was excited when her novel was published.... but it's not worth reading, alas.  Well, she can't do EVERYthing, but it doesn't lessen my admiration.

@Mean Old Lady
try her romance novels ( as Selena Montgomery). They're fun. Available as E- books in places.
@Anita there‚Äôs a theme?
@Paul What did you think the starred clues were starred for?

@Anita

I had to go back and look again to discover that "take" goes with *both* halves of the entries. Very clever.
@Isabeau I guess being on the west coast it takes jokes 3 hours longer to get there.
@Mr Dave  I think a lot of people have still missed that, even though the hint says that it applies to "each half" of the answers.

@Mike
Oaky-dokey!

@Mike

Just when we need them to fight the drop in temperature,
they turn yellow.

School's open.  The School of Hard Equi-nox.

@Al  in Pittsburgh
You're rushing the season....oh, wait.  You're in NY State; I take that back.  I miss our NE Ohio FALLs, full of color and crisp temps.  (There IS a silver maple on our block here...not a patch on the REal Deal. Sigh)

@Mike
I autumn make a comment that rakes you over the coals for those.
@Mike We are going to hold off on applying a Spoonerism to your opening line.

@Mike

Acorny yes, but not really treesonous.

@Eric Hougland

Eeeew is right on!! Wonder how long it took them to clean and air the car out...  It took us a while and we had more space than in a car. Yikes! It's been like... 16 or 17 years now but it still lingers in my memory so vividly. 

Fun thing about it though is that I'm now the undisputed champ of smelling icky things. Not sure I really want that title, but occasionally, I'll be like, "Eeew, what's that smell?" and he'll be like, "What smell?" and I'll be like, "There's a smell. Remember the turkey, man‚ÄîTHE TURKEY!!" 

See, I smelled it the second I got out of the car in our attached garage... and it got worse and worse as we approached and went in the door. He couldn't smell it until he was down the stairs and nearly to the laundry room, where the freezer lived and died‚Äîno longer cold‚Äîbut definitely alone... 

I could not believe he couldn't smell it when I couldn't stand to be in the house. Lucky guy, though, I guess... just hope he doesn't miss out on any deadly odors without me there to guide his way.  Har!

@Eric Hougland
Yum.  
I just had a large serving of chicken broth (clear liquids all day) and now I'm really sorry about that.  I can smell it from here.


It's too bad they're not on the coast; spoiled chicken is the best bait for your crab trap!
@Mean Old Lady may I recommend adding some parsnips, celery, carrots, onion, dill, and chicken.  It‚Äôll taste like stone soup.

@Paul
ha ha...it's a prep day, with no solid foods, NPO after midnight, and a 4 a.m. wake-up time.  
I've had happier days....but!
Stone Soup!  I used to play that with the kids when they were very small!  (I had actually boiled some smooth stones from the Merced River for the 'recipe.')  After they brought their secreted veggies out of hiding, we made the soup and had it for supper!    I hadn't thought of that in years!  Thanks so much for your fun note!

@Mean Old Lady

Sorry to put you off your food.

Jeremy,

What (or whom) are you questioning? Yes, the revealer says to "take" each half of the answers with starred clues, just as you've "taken" three of them.

@Jeremy Although one may certainly take a puff if one were so inclined, the phrase is ‚Äútake a powder.‚Äù I think it‚Äôs related to women popping into the rest room to powder their nose and refers to taking a short break.

MOL,

The revealer says "a hint," 
not "use these exact words." 

Would you say "Is this powder taken?"

@Lisa Marshall someone else further up pointed out that it might be related to the type of powder which would give you energy and allow you to run far away quickly.  I don‚Äôt know the answer‚Ä¶but the cocaine explanation is more interesting.

@Lewis:

OVER LOOK
BATH TIME
CARD STOCK

ok, y‚Äôall, keep it going!

@Cat Lady Margaret
OVER works both fore and aft!

@B

That sounds bad.  What do you mean "blipped" on?
@B Contact NYTGames@nytimes.com. They can fix your streak.

@Francis

Well this time it seemed to finish normally, with the congrats page fully filled in and the jingle chimed.  But then I noticed a partial blue state in the Archive section and my "solve rate" stood at 99.99%.

Prior to that I had seen a couple of "our site is having trouble" messages, so something was already amiss.

On previous events the congrats page and/or jingle failed to fully load.

It feels so silly asking to have it repaired but I guess I'll have to do it again.  I only brought it up here in case it was a system wide issue.  Apparently not.  Thanks.

@Lolo,

The clue made me think that FARMER would be a good answer, with a little work. The old joke is that a farmer is ‚Äúa man outstanding in his field‚Äù.

@Andrzej

I thought it was cute enough but I did feel like the odd person out yesterday, on Sunday's puzzle. Not a huge fan, but also, that's okay.

Strangely, I never mind feeling like the odd person out. Or the odd person in either. It all works for me!!

Curious though, since you're a self-proclaimed atheist, why on earth would highway to hell be played at your funeral? If there is no heaven, I assume there is no hell.....

Sorry, maybe I shouldn't comment when I'm on my second martini and it's a little too late at night!  üòÇ But I know you're good with all the things!!  Which is one of the many things that's awesome about you!!

@Andrzej

It's true, I enjoyed it less back then when I didn't fit in... Being young is hard. 

Being older is hard and different ways, but it's more physical than those emotional weird young ways.

So now, I feel like maybe it was good preparation for... I don't know, something.

I have a big fan of inappropriate humor so, I can support that!! 

Please do make sure that I am invited to your funeral, assuming you go before me...!!  üòÇüòÇüòÇ

@Andrzej

So sorry, I should have really done a good look over of my voice to text.... It made some errors, but I think they're understandable at least.

@Steve L
I guess he's gearing up, eh?
LOL
A friend's daughter found a stray kitten--jet black--and named her LUCYFER, as well. 
We should ask Andrzej what color the puppy is!

@Andrzej

That's so great!  As for me, these last like 8 10 months I've been dealing with some bizarre horrid  nerve pain, which has been validated on nerve conduction tests at the neurologist's office... So trying to figure that stuff out.  That's a little tough lately, but what are you going to do!? 

I have lost a couple of friends lately who don't believe that there's any real issue and just told me to walk it off...

Crazy!

@Andrzej

Please don't be mad, but I already slipped your funeral deejay 100 z≈Çotych to play "Candle in the Wind".

@HeathieJ

Sorry to hear that you've been in pain.
But telling a friend that you don't believe that they are in pain?  That's almost inconceivable.
Perhaps you're better off without such "friends".
Emus ate my reply to all of you ü´§

@HeathieJ
Years ago, in the fallout from an op, I was suffering horrible nerve pain from a drain that had been yanked out of my axilla, and when I went for my follow-up with the perp doc, he said, "You're not looking well. What's the wrong?"  I said, "I've been in a lot of pain." He frowned and said, "Hmm.  But what's really the matter?"  I was speechless.

Nerve pain is the worst, and your (former) friends won't really get the message until they've had to deal with it themselves.  I hope yours is diminishing and gone before too much longer. (I'd say I feel for you, but the literal meaning of that makes shudder.)

Take care of yourself, and we'll all be sending you good karma.

@The X-Phile

Thank you!  And agreed! And it was always in the context of, "I just care about you." ü§Ø Nahhh, I know what caring and being cared about is‚Äîand that behavior is not it.

@dutchiris

Thank you so much!! I'm sorry you had to deal with it too‚Äîand also weren't believed. 

On the real bad days, it's completely excruciating. I wouldn't wish this on anyone, even those who don't believe me. 

I appreciate your empathy and kind thoughts!!

@HeathieJ

Yikes. Not what you want to hear at all.
@Andrzej For me, it was slower than my usual Monday time, so yes. On a few, I needed a several crosses to complete them.

@Jacqui J
I already had the B in place, but I did think TOP was more accurate in so far as common usage.  TAB is for typing!
@jp inframan Send a complaint to NYTGames@nytimes.com

@jp inframan
If you solve in Firefox, install uBlock Origin. Make sure you get the real one, from author Raymond Hill. It will have like 5,000 ratings.

When it's installed, you can right-click on the banner and select "block element." I use this to block those obnoxious banners whenever they pop up.

And if for some reason you want to keep seeing regular ads here, you can turn off the ad blocker function for this site.
@valb tnx will do
@Katie Tnx. I use chrome esp for synch. Maybe I'll just do the Wapo puzzle for a while instead. Yrs ago as a teen I would switch over to the Herald Trib on occasion.

@jp inframan

there was a Chrome fix posted Saturday.
@Linda Jo Where do I find it? Or do I need a time machine?
@jp inframan on the occasion where something doesn‚Äôt fit on the screen where it really needs to I‚Äôll set the browser size resolution to 90%.
@Paul I do that too but this banner takes up so much RE that the clues get microscopic. üòí
@jp inframan https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/4a31a7?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

@Linda Jo - Thanks for the link. Actually I figured that out but it's not (as we used to say when I was a computer programmer) an elegant solution. Hoping I don't have to do it each time on each of my 3 machines.
@Linda Jo - Same fix no longer works. No reply from NYTGames.com. May be time to switch to WAPO. üòí

@Bruce
In the sense of ‚Äúrapidly depart without explanation,‚Äù the phrase appears to be mostly used in entertainment in the 1940s. Previously, it had been used in the sense of ‚Äútake medicine‚Äù a few hundred years before. Seems to have disappeared quickly in the 1950s.

@Ant

@Michael Hendler mine looks like stairs‚Ä¶.but that includes all of the archive‚Ä¶and by the nature of it being non Will Shortz and not involved in any steaks I would come back to them and do them randomly.  Which pushed my averages much higher than my typical for the puzzles in the streak.

@Michael Hendler

You'd break your neck on my "stairs."

The jump from Monday to Tuesday is barely noticeable (22 seconds), Tues to Wed considerably more (1:04), Wed to Thurs a giant one (3:32), another minuscule jump to Fri (21 seconds), a hefty one to Sat (3:51), and of course a big one from Sat to Sun (4:48).

On the other hand, this past Sat took me a few minutes longer than Sun did.

@Steve L

Your stairs sound much like mine.

@Michael Ender This is a very interesting idea - I've solved  a guesstimated ~2500 puzzles, and my times follow an increasing curve through the week with one weird exception. Mon-Fri step up from 5 to 13 minutes, Saturday's up to 16, then Sunday jumps to 26. Except for Thursday, which bucks the trend and is almost 90 seconds faster than Wednesday. Now I'm baffled by this, maybe I've subconsciously biased towards Thursday puzzles in the archives as I've gotten better at solving?

@Michael Hendler - I've solved 1238 puzzles to date, and my Thursday average is currently the highest/worst of the weekdays. Other than that, my stairs go up normally from Monday to Sunday, though Saturday and Sunday are nearly equal at the moment.
@Dave Maybe you  grasp  the Thursday theme  early and use it to ease over the rest of the puzzle.

A little bird told me. Or maybe it was a not-so-subtle hint from what you had to say on the themed puzzle from a few weeks ago ‚Ä¶

Just getting back from the memorial service for my sister-in-law in Houston. A lot of sadness, of course, but there is something to be said about being together with all of your family from all over the country.  One 16 yo nephew that I hadn‚Äôt seen since he was a baby, and his 13 yo sister whom I had never seen! There was so much love and support there and a genuine liking of everyone there. I realize more and more how vitally important community is. It‚Äôs certainly strengthened the bond between me and both of my brothers.  

So sorry to hear about your pain issues. It‚Äôs got to be very frustrating. It‚Äôs not like a broken arm or leg that everyone can immediately see and sympathize with and voluntarily offer some THC.  I do hope that you will have some kind of relief soon. 

Glad to be the one to let you know about Strands today üòä! Have fun!

@NYC Traveler

ü§£ You may be on to something! I have remarkably little experience with THC but am not opposed to the idea, especially if people just offer it to me... and especially especially if they combine it with TLC. ü§£

Thanks for the update! I've been wondering how it's going for you and your family, so I really appreciate you sharing! I'm very glad you were able to strengthen your relationships and be surrounded with so many loving family members in such a time of grief. What a difference that sort of love and support makes.  Grief and loss is so hard and I'm sure your brother felt greatly comforted by you and your family.

I read something recently that really stuck out to me, "We are wounded in community and we heal in community." (Rich Villodas) 

It seems kind of obvious in a way, but it jumped out at me... I don't know that we always think about it when we are hurting. Something about the "pull yourself up by your own bootstraps" mentality in this country, which shows up in so many weird ways. When it's healthy, like yours, it's a beautiful thing‚Äîcommunity! I'm so glad you are experiencing this with your family. 

Thanks for your good wishes, too! Despite those couple of naysayers, I'm grateful for all the love and support in my life through this current ordeal‚Äîboth with my family and friends who I know in person‚Äîand through our lovely community here. üíô

Now about that THC you're voluntarily offering me...!!  üòè
